awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Towards End-to-End Computer-Assisted Fact-Checking
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop ClaimBuster, an end-to-end system for computer-assisted fact-checking. This system will monitor live discourses, social media, and news to catch factual claims, detect matches with a curated repository of fact-checks from professionals, and deliver the matches instantly to readers and viewers. For various types of new claims not checked before, ClaimBuster will automatically check them against knowledge databases and report if they are truthful. For novel claims where humans must be brought into the loop, the system will provide algorithmic and computational tools to assist laypersons and professionals in understanding and vetting the claims. ClaimBuster, upon completion of the proposed work, is positioned to become the first-ever automated fact-checking system for use on a broad spectrum of factual claims. Its use will be expanded to verify claims in various types of narratives, discourses and documents such as sports news, legal documents, and financial reports. It can benefit a large base of potential users including consumers, publishers, corporate competitors, and legal professionals, among others. It directly benefits consumers by improving information accuracy and transparency. It helps news organizations speed their fact-checking process and also ensure the accuracy of their own news stories. Businesses can use ClaimBuster to identify falsehoods in their competitors' and their own reports and press releases. It also assists professionals such as lawyers in verifying documents.

ClaimBuster will use database query, data mining, and natural language processing techniques to aid fact-checking. The detailed research tasks in this project will be as follows. (1) Investigate how to model factual claims and produce their internal representations. For this, the team will create taxonomies of claim templates in different domains, categorize claims based on the taxonomies, and generate internal representations through semantic parsing of the claims' textual forms. Such domain-specific modeling and internal representation of claims will enable novel methods and systematic, coherent solutions for other components of the system. (2) For algorithmic fact-checking, they will devise novel methods for translating claims into structured queries, keyword queries and natural language questions. Results of these queries over general and domain-specific databases and knowledge graphs will be compared with the answers embedded in the claims themselves, to verify if the claims check out. (3) By viewing claims as parameterized queries, they will develop methods based on perturbation analysis to find counter-arguments to claims and to find "interesting" factlets from datasets. These results will help ClaimBuster in identifying "cherry-picking" claims -- claims that are correct but misleading.

por.por_cntn:
In today's world, where news, media, and social media are abundant and easily accessible, it has become imperative to fact-check the information we come across. If left unchecked, misinformation and disinformation can have severe consequences. For instance, false information about a virus and its treatment can prompt people to take dangerous and ineffective remedies, thus jeopardizing their health. Falsehoods about elections can undermine the democratic process and erode the legitimacy of elected officials. Furthermore, misinformation and disinformation can undermine the credibility of experts and institutions, eroding people's trust in scientists, journalists, politicians, and other public figures. Inaccurate or misleading information about natural disasters, terrorist attacks, or other emergencies can cause widespread panic, chaos, and poor decision-making. Moreover, false information can worsen social and political divisions, as it can fuel hatred, bigotry, and intolerance, leading to the polarization of society. False information about stocks, investments, or companies can also result in significant financial losses for individuals and businesses, while misleading advertising or false claims about products or services can misguide consumers into making poor and even harmful purchasing decisions.

Fact-checking plays a crucial role in curbing the spread of misinformation and disinformation. With the prevalence of false information, fact-checking will become increasingly crucial in safeguarding individuals and society from the harms posed by such information. Additionally, it promotes informed decision-making, holds public figures accountable for the statements they make, and helps develop critical thinking skills. While fact-checking is currently primarily carried out by human experts, it is essential to develop automated solutions and computer-assisted tools for fact-checking to keep up with the scale and complexity of widespread misinformation and disinformation.

This project advances the research and development of ClaimBuster, an end-to-end system for computer-assisted fact-checking. ClaimBuster uses database query, machine learning, and natural language processing techniques to aid fact-checking. It monitors live discourses, social media, and news to spot check-worthy factual claims, detects matches with a curated repository of professional fact-checks, and delivers the matches instantly to readers and viewers. For various types of new claims not checked before, ClaimBuster automatically translates them into queries against knowledge databases and reports if they check out. For claims where humans must be brought into the loop, ClaimBuster provides algorithmic and computational tools to assist lay persons and professionals in understanding and verifying the claims.

Specifically, this project accomplished several outcomes important to ClaimBuster. First, it created the latest claim spotting model in ClaimBuster based on the popular pre-trained language model BERT and adversarial training. The claim spotting model scores textual sentences based on their likelihood of being important factual claims that are worth checking. This component is key to helping fact-checkers prioritize their work and improving their efficiency. Second, the project extended an approach called frame semantics to model fine-grained semantic and structured information in factual claims. This modeling provides the foundation for future advancement of several components in ClaimBuster, including matching clams and querying reference knowledge base for automation of fact-checking certain types of claims. Third, it created deep learning models to automatically analyze factual claims based on the aforementioned modeling. Fourth, it developed approaches for vetting statistical claims on temporal data. Fifth, it created tools for pop-up delivery of fact-checks. Finally, it created several data annotation tools, for generating a taxonomy of misinformation in specific topic domains such as vaccine misinformation as well as for collecting labeled datasets in order to train the several aforementioned deep learning models.

The project website http://claimbuster.org/ provides various details about the project and makes available its machine learning models, datasets, and tools. Particularly, ClaimBuster?s API has been regularly used by the fact-checker community to create daily email alerts to professional fact-checkers with the most check-worthy claims from TV program transcripts and social media. These alerts have led to multiple claims featured in articles by fact-checking outlets.

The project's eternal quest, the "Holy Grail," is a completely automatic fact-checking platform that can detect a claim as it appears in real time, and instantly provide the reader or viewer of the claim with a rating about its accuracy. While the "Holy Grail" of fact-checking general claims will remain remote in the foreseeable future, it serves as an ultimate yardstick that will drive fundamental breakthroughs on multiple fronts of data-driven fact-checking. ClaimBuster is making strides toward this quest.
